title: Dangers of Poor Sleep
content: Poor sleep can lead to Alzheimer’s risk, mental health issues, and memory problems. It can also increase the risk of heart disease, cancer, and sexual dysfunction. Poor sleep can have penetrating effects on metabolism and genetics.

title: Strategies for Better Sleep
content: Practical and tactical ways to improve sleep include optimizing the wind down routine with appropriate lights, temperature, and relaxation. Avoiding alcohol, which disrupts sleep, is also recommended. Consistent wake up time is crucial for good sleep.

title: Impact of Diet and Exercise on Sleep
content: Eating food too close to bedtime can lead to digestive issues and raise core body temperature, which can disrupt sleep. Exercise impacts sleep positively if done earlier in the day, but should be avoided within 2 hours of bedtime as it can increase core body temperature and change hormone levels.

title: Sleep and Health
content: Sleep quality affects appetite and can lead to anxiety, cortisol increase, and weight gain. It also impacts sex hormones and romantic relationships. Poor sleep can speed up the aging process. Sleep is considered the best insurance policy for lifespan and healthspan.

title: Sleep Aids and Supplements
content: Melatonin can be used for sleep improvement, but sleeping pills can be dangerous. Alternatives and cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia can be useful. CBD and THC can potentially be used for sleep. However, overuse of sleep aids can lead to too much sleep, which can also be harmful.

title: Effects of Sleep Deprivation on Health
content: Likelihood of injury risk markedly decreased. Your ability to even sweat and perspire is determined by how much sleep that you get. The time it takes to reach physical exhaustion increases. When you are sleep deprived, the brain receives a signal that is not dissimilar to starvation. It releases a cascade of hormones that change your appetite profile. So you’ll want to eat more. And you’re less satisfied after you eat food. This is because when the body undergoes sleep deprivation, the brain thinks, “Oh, I must be under conditions of starvation… I must stay awake and forage for food.” But it’s a “fake starvation signal” which increases a hormone called ghrelin (which makes you want to eat more) and it suppresses a hormone called leptin (which gives you a feeling of fullness).

title: Anxiety, Cortisol, and Weight Gain: An Awful Feedback Loop of Sleep Deprivation
content: Cortisol also plays a role in weight gain. It is a very anabolic hormone to adipose tissue and a very catabolic hormone to muscle tissue. It also affects the liver and glycogen stores via hepatic glucose output. Chronic undersleeping leads to hypercortisolemia. That is then causing a cascade of biology that is nonoptimal. More cortisol means more anxiety. More anxiety means less sleep. Less sleep means more cortisol (and more anxiety). An awful feedback loop.

title: How to Optimize Your Wind Down Routine: Lights, Temperature, & Relaxation
content: Lighting is probably one of the most underappreciated factors that is contributing to poor sleep. Most people keep their bedrooms too warm at night. Ideally, bedroom temp should be 65-68 degrees fahrenheit. In the last hour before bed, try to find a wind-down routine that involves at least one of the three following: Relaxing body movements, Meditation, Journaling.

title: How Alcohol Disrupts Sleep (and Contributes to Alzheimer’s Disease)
content: Alcohol is the most misunderstood sleep aid. It frequently causes wake ups (fragmented sleep). Alcohol inhibits vasopressin, so it’s a potent diuretic, which means you’ll need to get up to urinate more frequently. It also negatively impacts: resting heart rate, heart rate variability, temperature and respiratory rate.

title: Sleep’s Impact on Sex Hormones, and Romantic Relationships
content: Sleeping with someone who snores or moves around a lot can contribute to poor sleep. Sleep apnea is a very serious condition that can “strip years from your life if it’s untreated”. About 80% of people who have sleep apnea are currently undiagnosed. Sleep apnea/snoring can cause poor sleep in both people in the same bed. Sex hormones that are highly dependent on sleep. Men who are sleeping just sort of four to five hours a night, will have a level of testosterone which is probably 10 years aged. In females, for every one hour of extra sleep that a female gets, they have somewhere between a 13 to 15% increase in the desire to be intimate with a partner.

title: Performance, Accuracy, and Minimizing the Damage of Shift Work
content: Accuracy of tasks decreases with sleep deprivation. If you must work a job that includes shift work, the best set of recommendations is to try to stay on longer bouts of that shift work. Don’t do flip flop shift work where you are on for two days, off for three days, on for four days, and so on.

title: Sleep Routines
content: You can still sleep in separate locations but develop a good night routine and a good morning routine. In the evening, make a habit of going into the bedroom at the time that the first person likes to go to bed. Hang out for a bit and say goodnight to each other. In the morning, reverse engineer the same trick. You get 99% of the benefit of co-sleeping without the need to actually co-sleep and you sleep better.

title: Sound Machines and Electrical Stimulation for Sleep
content: There are 2 types of sound manipulation that are most commonly used: Sound blocking and Rhythmic frequencies. Sound blocking includes white noise, pink noise, etc. There is no evidence right now that they’re necessarily harmful for your sleep. As long as they’re not too loud and too close. Rhythmic frequencies involve electrical stimulation. It is an electroceutical where we insert a small amount of voltage into the brain using a set of pads that usually sit on the forehead. We try to “sing in time” with those deep sleep brainwaves to amplify the size of them. In doing so, we can actually almost double the amount of memory benefit that you get from sleep.

title: Supercharging Sleep Stages Using Technology
content: To be able to supercharge our brains using at-home stimulation, we will first need: Much more accurate in our ability to stage sleep on our devices. Those devices would have to be connected directly to, meaning speaking with the device that’s putting in the voltage. Will this improve sleep efficiency and allow for less total sleep? We just don’t know as of now.

title: Sleep as a Health Insurance
content: Sleep is a life insurance policy. It is probably the most democratic health care insurance policy that you have, or health care system. Sleep essentially is a life support system. Sleep acts like a superordinate node in the biological equation of health. If you optimize sleep, you’re doing as much as probably you can from the health regard standpoint in terms of increasing your insurance for a longer life.

title: Melatonin for Sleep Improvement
content: Melatonin can help the timing of your sleep, but it doesn’t necessarily change the quantity and the quality of that sleep. However, it may actually have a potential benefit for deep non REM sleep. It can be efficacious under at least two conditions: When you’re jet lagged and you’re traveling and for people who are typically over the age of 50.

title: Dangers of Sleeping Pills and Alternatives
content: Ambien and Lunesta are sedative hypnotics and don’t actually get you into your good sleep stages. The FDA updated its mortality risk warnings regarding those sleeping pills because of this increased risk of death. In 2016, the American College of Physicians said sleeping pills must no longer be the first line recommendation for insomnia… it has to be something else called Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBTI). CBTI is a nonpharmacological, psychological method working with a therapist and they try to understand where your sleep problems are at and create a bespoke solution for you, the individual.

title: Effects of Benadryl and Tylenol PM on Sleep
content: Benadryl-induced sleep has some of the risks associated with sleeping pills. It’s less potent in terms of that bad consequence and outcome to sleep. For Tylenol PM, there is not good enough data yet to suggest that it’s either good or bad.

title: Effects of Benzodiazepines on Sleep
content: Benzodiazepines, such as Xanax and Valium, should be used carefully and only in the most dire of circumstances. They may have similar negative consequences as Ambien and Lunesta, even with just 3 to 18 pills per year.

title: Effects of GHB and Xyrem on Sleep
content: Xyrem or GHB are drugs that appear to increase the amount of deep sleep that you have because it puts your brain into a more sort of sedated slow rhythm. However, a closer look in the lab shows it may not look like naturalistic sleep. Xyrem seems to be detrimental to sleep spindles, which are critical for things like learning memory and brain plasticity. When you take GHB or Xyrem, the amount of sleep spindle activity is often decreased.

title: Effects of THC and CBD on Sleep
content: THC speeds up the time with which you fall asleep but it seems to actually block REM sleep and people build up a dependency so when you stop taking THC you typically have “rebound insomnia”. CBD as a sleep aid looks “increasingly promising”. It may reduce in core body temperature, can be an anti-anxiety solution and does not blunt REM sleep, nor create rebound insomnia when you stop taking it.

title: Challenges in Developing Effective Sleeping Aid
content: Developing an effective sleeping aid is challenging due to the complexity of brainwaves and brain oscillations, vast changes in neurochemistry during different stages of sleep, and the complexity of neural network activities during different stages of sleep.

title: Effects of Oversleeping
content: There is a pathological condition called idiopathic hypersomnia where people have an excessive amount of sleepiness. Depressed people also tend to sleep more. However, it might prove hard to oversleep naturally without something else causing it (i.e. illness). Nine hours of sleep is not a problem, but 14+ hours is where concern arises.

title: Effects of Poor Sleep on Aging
content: Poor sleep can increase your biological age. This is determined by factors such as telomeres, skin resilience, and heart health. A lack of sleep will artificially age you from a biological standpoint.

title: Resilience to Sleep Deprivation
content: People are impacted differently by sleep deprivation. Some people might be less affected in some ways but that generally means they might be more affected in another way. Different people are differentially vulnerable to sleep deprivation in different domains of brain function.

title: Understanding Insufficient Sleep
content: We’re starting to try to see if we can find out what is common and universal in terms of its sensitivity to insufficient sleep, and then separate that from other things that are more individual specific in terms of their sensitivity to insufficient sleep.

title: Chronotypes and Sleep Schedule
content: Finding your optimal sleep schedule is important. It is genetic… it’s called your chronotype. Society has the distribution of different chronotypes so you can be a strong evening type, or you could be a strong morning type. It’s very difficult to change your chronotype. You might be able to wiggle it around by about 30 minutes from your natural rhythm, but not much more than that or you will start sacrificing sleep quality.

title: Chronotypes and Relationship Problems
content: Couples who have marked chronotype mismatches typically struggle. In a survey, almost 40% of people admitted that sleep issues including sleep mismatching in terms of typical timing caused a significant relationship to end as a consequence.

title: Determining Your Chronotype
content: Morningness / Eveningness questionnaire (MEQ) can help you figure out your chronotype.

title: Defining Sleep Efficiency and How to Improve It
content: Sleep duration is the actual sleep, not just time in bed. Sleep efficiency is the time you are asleep divided by the time you are in bed. Sleep opportunity is the time you plan to be in bed with the opportunity to sleep.

title: Correcting Insomnia: A Counterintuitive Approach
content: If you’re someone who’s struggling with insomnia and you’re lying in bed awake a lot of the time, you may need to decrease your time in bed to increase sleep pressure. It’s counterintuitive, but one of the tools in the CBTI toolbox is to shorten the sleep opportunity.

title: Improving Kids' Sleep
content: Referring to kids from 5th grade up through high school, their natural inclination is to go to bed later and wake up later. Most school start way too early. So, what can the average parent do to help their kids get better sleep? Regularity, removing all toys and electronics from the bedroom, relaxing routine, and daylight exposure can help.
